summary: Pepper...and Salt

summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Aug. 9, 2011

headline: Debt for Sale: U.S. Will Unload $35 Billion
summary: The Treasury plans to sell $35 billion in four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: For Sale: 117,00 Acres, With Waterfall
summary: An estate nearly half the size of Hong Kong is for sale in Australia. It includes a house, staff quarters, aircraft hangar, horse stable, wetland reserve and waterfall.

headline: State Firm to Keep Stake in Bharti Hexacom
summary: After years of trying to sell its 30% stake in Bharti Hexacom, a unit of Bharti Airtel, government-owned Telecommunications Consultants India has decided to defer the share sale.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, August 10, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: London Riots Put Matches in Danger
summary: Unrest in London has resulted in the cancellation of Wednesday's soccer exhibition between England and the Netherlands. Plus, the U.S. men's soccer team seeks to regain its footing.

headline: Asian Markets Continue Slide
summary: Most Asian stock markets ended sharply lower Tuesday after a massive selloff in the U.S. Monday undermined already-fragile confidence, although markets came off early lows and Australian shares finished higher.

headline: Hasn't Wakefield Waited Long Enough?
summary: Red Sox knuckleballer Tim Wakefield is stuck in his pursuit of his 200th career victory.

headline: Youku.com Posts Loss, Revenue Surges
summary: Youku.com's second-quarter revenue nearly tripled from a year earlier, although the Chinese online-video company continued to operate at a loss as the market becomes increasingly competitive.

headline: Thirachai Named Thai Finance Minister
summary: Thailand's King granted a royal endorsement for Yingluck's Cabinet, which will see former Thai SEC head Thirachai Phuvanatnaranubala become finance minister.

headline: Officials Say Man Shot by Police Didn't Fire Gun
summary: An oversight group probing the matter said there was no evidence so far that Mark Duggan fired at police before being shot fatally in the chest by an officer in North London last week.

headline: How Fuel Rules Will Look on the Road
summary: In coming years, the auto industry will have to roughly double new car and light truck fuel efficiency by 2025 to an average of 54.5 miles per gallon. A look at what the changes will look like on the road.

headline: Turkey Demands Syria Stop Killing Its Civilians
summary: Turkey has demanded the Syrian government act to stop the killing of civilians and will be watching developments there in the days ahead, its foreign minister said after returning from talks in Damascus.

headline: G-20 Members Turn Up Intervention Volume
summary: Some members of the Group of 20 leading nations turned up the volume for concerted action to quell the turmoil sweeping through financial markets—but action so far is hard to find.

headline: Patience on AOL Wears Thin
summary: AOL stock sank 26% as the online media company reported ongoing shortfalls in its advertising business and cut its outlook.Investors have grown increasingly leery of the company's turnaround strategy.

headline: U.K. Riots Continue
summary: Violence flared anew Tuesday evening beyond London.

headline: European Business Briefs
summary: Tepco's loss widens, RWE swings to a loss, and Disney profit rises.

headline: GM Share Sale on Hold
summary: The Obama administration has put on hold plans to sell the rest of its stake in GM because the auto maker's shares have slumped this year amid turbulence in the stock market.

headline: S&P Cuts Ratings on 11,000 Muni Issues
summary: Standard and Poor's downgraded more than 11,000 public finance issues to keep them in line with its newly lowered rating on federal government debt.

headline: Colombia's Soccer Coach Quits
summary: The head coach of Colombia's national soccer team, Hernan Dario Gomez, resigned following a weekend incident at a bar in which he allegedly punched a woman who criticized his coaching skills.

headline: Credit Union Group Sues Goldman Over Losses
summary: Federal regulators sued Goldman Sachs, accusing the investment bank of violating securities laws in the sale of $1.2 billion in mortgage-backed securities.

headline: PG&E Taps DTE Chairman as New Chief
summary: California utility PG&E has hired Anthony Earley, executive chairman of DTE Energy, as its new chief executive.

headline: Cargill's Earnings Slip 7%
summary: Cargill said its earnings slipped 7% on weakness in energy trading and food ingredients, but remained bullish on demand for agricultural commodities.

headline: Late Boost for Crude
summary: After settling below $80 a barrel for the first time in nearly 10 months, Nymex oil futures turned higher in late trading, driven by a report from an oil industry group that showed a large drop in U.S. crude stockpiles.

headline: MBIA Profit Drops 89% on Derivatives Losses
summary: MBIA's second-quarter earnings dropped 89% as it swung to derivative losses from significant gains in the prior year, but the bond insurer's adjusted bottom line improved on lower expenses.

headline: Alliance HealthCare Services, Stereotaxis: Biggest Price Decliners (AIQ, STXS)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Decliners.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Falling Oil Prices to Squeeze Canada's Oil-Sands Growth
summary: The drop in crude-oil prices from above $110 a barrel in April to below $80 Tuesday isn't good news for Canada's oil-sands industry, which boasts large reserves that require high up-front costs for development.

headline: Taiwan Opposition Party Alleges Chinese Hacking
summary: Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party said it has been the target of a Chinese hacking campaign that since March has made daily incursions into its computers, complicating its preparations for presidential elections in January.

headline: Mutual Funds See No Forced Selling, but Await Ripple Effect
summary: Mutual-fund companies said they won't be forced to sell securities as a result of Standard & Poor's downgrade to U.S. government debt Monday, but said the magnitude of the downgrade's ripple effects across the industry remains to be seen.

headline: USDA Proposes Livestock Tracking System
summary: The USDA proposed a new, mandatory system for tracking cattle, poultry and other farm animals to pinpoint the origin of diseases that can spread through herds and halt exports.

headline: European Stocks Slide
summary: European stock markets tumbled Monday as the downgrade of the U.S. credit rating helped sap confidence in the global economy, and as investors were underwhelmed by the ECB's move to buy Italian and Spanish bonds.

headline: Businesses Count the Clean-Up Cost
summary: As the U.K. government pledged tougher measures to prevent another night of street violence, shops and businesses across England tallied the cost of a three-day rioting binge and local councils cleaned up heavily vandalized streets and shopping districts.

headline: Treasury Report Finds Fewer Small Businesses
summary: A new government analysis suggests that the nation's pool of small-business owners may be smaller than officials previously thought.

headline: Tepco Loss Widens to $7.4 Billion on Nuclear Crisis
summary: Tokyo Electric Power logged a net loss of $7.4 billion for the three months through June, plummeting even deeper into the red on higher fuel and compensation costs as it continues to grapple with the nuclear crisis

headline: First, The Downgrade; What's Next?
summary: In the two sessions following S&P's market-rattling U.S. debt downgrade, investors parsed every existing economic detail to figure out what's next for stocks and the dollar. If recent history is an indicator, they're not going to find anything definitive.

headline: Photos of the Day: Aug. 9
summary: In today's photos, a stock-price board in Taiwan shows the market's swings, a spectator at the PGA Championship cools off in Georgia, a rioter horses around in London, and more.

headline: Markets Slump, and Unbowed Investor Seeks Deals
summary: As traders and fund managers across Asia scrambled to square positions to cut losses, some retail investors in Hong Kong became surprisingly opportunistic, hoping to seize the local market's accumulated declines as a time to buy.

headline: South Korea Bans Short Selling
summary: South Korea's market regulator said it will ban the short-selling of all publicly traded stocks from Aug. 10 to Nov. 9 as it tries to shore up a plunging share market.

headline: Lehman Brokerage Close to Payouts
summary: Lehman Brothers' U.S. brokerage business hopes to begin paying back some of its creditors by year's end.

headline: Wider Swings for Corn Prices Approved
summary: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission ruled the Chicago Board of Trade can let corn futures rise or fall by as much as 40 cents a bushel on a given day, up from the current limit of 30 cents.

headline: Norilsk Auditor Cites Lack of Disclosure on Stake Sale
summary: Norilsk Nickel's auditor said it hasn't received sufficient documents concerning a multibillion-dollar sale of an approximately 8% stake in the company in the last year, according to a document.

headline: MS Drug Shows Effectiveness
summary: Biogen Idec and Abbott reported positive data from experimental once-monthly multiple sclerosis drug.

headline: Quicksilver Shale-Well Data Subpoenaed by SEC
summary: Quicksilver Resources has received a subpoena from the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking documents pertaining to shale-well production, the producer of oil and natural gas said in a securities filing.

headline: Total Pursuing Exploration in Kenya, Official Says
summary: Plans by a unit of the French oil giant mark the latest sign of the East African country's rise as an international petroleum prospect.

headline: AIG Suit Against BofA Is Latest From Mortgage Meltdown
summary: Bond investors and regulators are stepping up their efforts to get others to pick up losses stemming from the mortgage meltdown. The latest to join the legal fray: American International Group, which filed suit against Bank of America on Monday.

headline: European Stocks End Losing Streak
summary: European stocks snapped a seven-session losing streak Tuesday, closing higher as investors stepped in to buy beaten-down shares after recent dramatic declines. The Stoxx Europe 600 gained 1.4%.

headline: Magna Earnings Slip Despite Sales Boost
summary: Auto-parts maker Magna posted a 24% rise in quarterly sales but saw its earnings slip due to operational inefficiencies at certain facilities and higher commodity costs.

headline: Ralcorp to Buy Sara Lee Unit
summary: Ralcorp added another twist as it stands in the crosshairs of a buyout offer from ConAgra, agreeing to pay $545 million for the Sara Lee unit that makes private-label refrigerated dough in North America.

headline: iStar Financial, Anacor Pharmaceuticals: Biggest Price Gainers (SFI, ANAC)
summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: China Again Faces Growth vs. Inflation Conundrum
summary: There are no easy answers for China's policy makers, with evidence of rising inflation and slowing growth presenting a conflict for Beijing.

headline: Rival Malaysian Airlines Bury the Hatchet
summary: Malaysia Airlines and budget carrier AirAsia agreed to swap shares and start collaborating in a bid to reduce competition and cut costs in one of Asia's key economies.

headline: iShares Barclays 1-3 Year Treasury Bond, SPDR Trust: Money Flow Leaders (SHY, SPY)
summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: A mulher de oito metros
summary: Uma estátua gigante de Marilyn Monroe está causando furor em Chicago.

headline: Truck Makers Face Fuel-Efficiency Rules
summary: The Obama administration will require truck manufacturers to meet new fuel-efficiency standards lowering carbon-dioxide emissions for large trucks and buses by as much as 20% by 2018.

headline: OPEC Shaves Demand Outlook
summary: OPEC trimmed its global oil demand growth forecast for 2011 and warned it could cut the outlook further, signaling that mounting economic woes are biting into the world's crude consumption.

headline: Cloud Descends Over Hong Kong IPOs
summary: The past week's market swoon has cast doubt over Hong Kong's initial public offering market, one of the world's largest, where at least 12 companies are lined up to raise more than US$19 billion in coming weeks.

headline: Apollo Global's Core Profit Jumps
summary: Apollo Global Management's second-quarter core earnings soared, buoyed by higher performance fees from its private-equity business.

headline: Finra Fines Citi $500,000 for Lax Oversight in Fraud Case
summary: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Citigroup $500,000 for failing to supervise a former sales assistant who allegedly misappropriated funds, falsified account records and engaged in unauthorized trades.

headline: Why 2011 Is Different From 2007
summary: Four years after the start of a chain of events that led to the collapse of Lehman Brothers, markets are again highly volatile. But a repeat of the forced selling that made the last crisis so toxic looks less likely.

headline: Fear Returns for U.S. Banks
summary: Bank stocks plunged 11% in their biggest one-day drop since April 2009, as investors questioned how well giant financial firms will weather an unprecedented downgrade of U.S. debt.

headline: S&P: Local Borrowers Can Still Be Triple-A
summary: Following its downgrade of the U.S. government's credit rating, Standard & Poor's whipsawed markets again by saying that downgrade doesn't necessarily imperil triple-A ratings for state and other local governments.

headline: Nestlé to Build Factory in Vietnam
summary: Swiss food giant Nestlé will spend $270 million building a new coffee factory in Vietnam and increase its sourcing of coffee from local farmers.

headline: Japan's Companies Face New Threats
summary: The March earthquake and soaring yen rocked Japanese companies. Now, the U.S. and European debt problems and the specter of a slowdown in developed economies threaten to overwhelm the remarkable resilience that many of those firms have shown.

headline: Ayala Land First-Half Profit Rises 35%
summary: Double-digit growth in real-estate sales and office and commercial rents lift profits for the Philippines largest developer..

headline: India Investors Relieved as Stocks Recover From Opening Losses
summary: Investors in India breathed a sigh of relief to see Indian stocks recover from their steep opening losses.

headline: Going Green With Bursts of Color
summary: Atlanta advertising firm 22squared Inc. recently completed a half-year-long renovation. It used recycled and repurposed materials, including wood flooring from a middle-school gymnasium in Oregon. The small business also cut power consumption by installing energy-efficient lights and eliminating 70% of its printers.

headline: Obama Adviser Bloom to Depart
summary: White House adviser Ron Bloom, who helped engineer the bailout and restructuring of GM and Chrysler, will leave his post by the end of August.

headline: Monday's Markets on the Front Page
summary: The global markets' tumble that followed S&P's downgrade made front page headlines around the world. See some examples.

headline: BHP Insources in the Pilbara
summary: BHP Billiton is shifting its approach to keeping mining costs down: cutting out the middleman.

headline: Sharpening the Mind With a Sword
summary: Hong Kong CEO practices iaido, an ancient Japanese martial art based on the sword techniques of the samurai.

headline: Satyam to Exit U.S. Exchange
summary: Satyam Computer Services, which is recovering from India's biggest corporate scandal, swung to a first-quarter consolidated net profit from a heavy loss the previous quarter, and then later unexpectedly announced plans to exit the U.S. stock market.

headline: Euro-Zone Leaders Need More Than Just Rhetoric
summary: The ECB's decision to extend its bond-purchase program to Spain and Italy may buy the euro zone some time, but it can't bring the currency area's fiscal crisis to an end. The fundamental problem remains political.

headline: Commodities: A West Side Story
summary: Precious metals, especially gold, and agricultural commodities have held up relatively well in the past week while oil and base metals have fallen by around 9%. It is hard to see that pattern reversing.

headline: Asean Says Region Safe Haven
summary: Investors and companies should look to Southeast Asia as they seek shelter from the world-wide markets meltdown, said the secretary general of the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

headline: EU Doesn't Plan Short-Selling Ban
summary: European financial regulators dismissed rumors of an imminent ban on short-selling to support battered markets, despite levels of volatility not seen since 2008.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise on Weak Auction
summary: A weak auction of 40-year debt pulled up Japanese government bond yields, and analysts said they could rise further if the U.S. Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee takes any steps that later prop up stock markets.

headline: RBI Extends Governor Subbarao's Term
summary: Faced with global economic instability, India's federal government has chosen continuity over change at the central bank, saying that it has extended governor Duvvuri Subbarao's term by two years.

headline: HSBC Puts Retail Investor Dark Pool On Ice
summary: HSBC put its plans to launch Hong Kong's first-ever dark pool for retail investors on ice, dimming prospects for the development of alternative liquidity pools in the Chinese territory.

headline: Mahindra, Ssangyong to Jointly Develop Vehicle Platforms
summary: Mahindra & Mahindra said it plans to develop vehicle platforms jointly with its South Korean unit Ssangyong Motor, the first of which is expected to be ready in three to four years.

headline: When Mindset Trumps Skill Set
summary: James Reed, chairman of recruitment company Reed, explains why bosses favor employees with a particular outlook when filling jobs

headline: The Tiger Car
summary: In 1925 the Maharaja of Kotah asked Rolls Royce to tailor-make a tiger-hunting car for him. Later this month it will be going under the hammer once again. In pictures.

headline: India Fuel Retailers Expect Earnings Boost
summary: India's state-run fuel retailers expect the recent fall in crude oil prices to help them trim daily losses from discounted fuel sales, reduce borrowings and improve earnings, company executives said

headline: Aussie Dollar's Slide Offers a Bit of Hope
summary: The Australian dollar's fall from its record level is a stark sign of the global turmoil affecting financial markets, but it provides a glimmer of hope for businesses that have suffered under the pressure of the surging currency.

headline: RWE Hit by German Nuclear Fallout
summary: German utility RWE said it swung to a net loss in the second quarter of 2011, driven mainly by additional costs related to Germany's decision to exit all nuclear energy by 2022 and a tax on nuclear fuel.

headline: German Exports Fall
summary: German exports fell in June on a global economic slowdown while imports continued to rise on robust domestic demand, likely dampening Germany's economic growth seen for the second quarter.

headline: Mumbai Oil Spill
summary: The oil spill from merchant ship MV RAK has reached Mumbai's shoreline. Some snapshots.

headline: China Vanke Net Profit Rises 5.9%
summary: China's largest property developer by market share, China Vanke, said its first-half net profit rose 5.9% from a year earlier due to strong housing demand amid continuing tightening in the sector.

headline: China's Conundrum: Trapped in Treasurys
summary: Frustrated as it is over U.S. debt policy, China—America's biggest foreign creditor—is expected to continue buying Treasury bonds, mostly because the alternatives for parking its giant pool of foreign reserve are limited.

headline: BP-Reliance Deal Cleared
summary: Reliance Industries said it has received the Indian government's formal approval to sell a 30% stake in 21 oil and gas production sharing contracts to BP.

headline: Indian Mutual Funds Open Up to Foreign Investors
summary: Indian capital markets regulator Securities and Exchange Board of India allowed foreign investors to buy local mutual funds, with a total limit of $10 billion for equity schemes and $3 billion for debt funds meant to invest in infrastructure.

headline: China Overseas Land Net Profit Up 35%
summary: Blue-chip Hong Kong developer China Overseas Land & Investment said its first-half net profit rose 35% from a year earlier, lifted by higher property sales.

headline: Why This Crisis Isn't Like 2008
summary: The bankers, investors and executives who look at today's problems through the prism of 2008 risk misjudging the issues confronting the economy, writes Francesco Guerrera.

headline: Chicago Contemporary
summary: Designed around a courtyard and featuring large windows, this three-story modern home in Chicago maximizes public spaces and minimizes private ones. It has five bedrooms, as well as several outdoor spaces.

headline: Corn, Wheat Swap Roles as Prices Surge
summary: In a reversal of historic patterns, the price of corn is higher than wheat, an anomaly that is upending commodities-trading strategies and changing what poultry producers feed their chickens.

headline: Amazon's Sales Tax Jungle Rates Little Sympath
summary: As a staunch economic conservative and owner of a small Arizona online retail company, I find it unconscionable that Amazon continues to cling to a Supreme Court ruling, which was put into place during the earliest days of e-commerce, in order to avoid charging sales tax ("Amazon Battles States Over Sales Tax," page one, Aug. 3).

headline: Reinsurer Seeks More From Berkshire
summary: Transatlantic Holdings left the door open to talks with Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway. But the reinsurer stopped short of accepting Berkshire's $3.25 billion takeover offer made Friday.

headline: MGM Resorts Improves Its Game
summary: MGM Resorts reported gains in revenue and profit as Las Vegas Strip casinos appeared to be in the midst of a slow period of recovery.

headline: Take-Two Swings to Loss
summary: Take-Two Interactive swung to a loss in its fiscal first quarter after videogame sales slumped from blockbuster levels last year.

headline: McGurn: They Once Loved Jimmy, Too
summary: Like Obama, Carter enjoyed the intellectuals' favor.

headline: Lights Out on the Bowery
summary: It's not quite curtains for the lighting district in Manhattan, but the outlook is dim for business owners in one of Manhattan's declining specialty areas.

headline: The Artist Who Keeps New York in Stitches
summary: Artist Agata Oleksiak has spent the last eight years enveloping everything from bicycles to Wall Street's "Charging Bull" sculpture to her own East Village apartment in a camouflage-patterned crochet.

headline: Depression Is No Plus For Leaders or Anyone
summary: I think that the conclusion of the article "Depression in Command—In Times of Crisis, Mentally Ill Leaders Can See What Others Don't" (Review, July 30) is superficial.

headline: Good as Gold
summary: None

headline: Envy at Twins Convention
summary: The Twinsburg festival exposed an inferiority complex that lurks in the world of multiples. Some fraternal twins and their parents think identical twins have all the fun.

headline: Beijing Sees Surprise Price Increase
summary: China's consumer-price index rose 6.5% in July from a year earlier, quicker than a 6.4% on-year rise in June, and more than economists had expected.

headline: Freddie Mac Says Loss Narrows
summary: Freddie Mac posted a $2.1 billion loss during the second quarter, down from a year-ago loss of $4.7 billion.

headline: GDF Close to CIC Deal
summary: GDF-Suez is close to selling a 30% stake in its exploration and production business to China Investment Corp., China's sovereign-wealth fund, for around $4.28 billion.

headline: Investor Jitters Move to France
summary: The cost of insuring French sovereign debt against default jumped to record highs, as investors took Standard and Poor's downgrade of the U.S. as a reason to question the ratings of other highly indebted sovereign nations.

headline: Hedge Funds Hit 'Sell'
summary: For all the talk of the need for investors to avoid panic, hedge funds have been dumping the shares and debt of many of their favorite companies, contributing to a downdraft in many stocks.

headline: A Search for 'Meaning'
summary: Sometimes you lose after midnight. Sometimes you win when your new boss wins and your old boss doesn't. What it means is up to you.

headline: Toner Scammer Now Headed to Jail
summary: A former employee of Manhattan's Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center was sentenced Monday to up to 7 ½ years in prison for stealing more than $1.5 million worth of printer toner to finance a life of luxury.

headline: McQueen Exhibition Makes Met Top 10
summary: A total of 661,509 visitors attended the Metropolitan Museum of Art's "Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty" exhibit, with more than 23,000 new members signing up during the run.

headline: Little Magic in Shares of Disney's Kingdom
summary: Shares of Walt Disney Co. are looking pretty cheap. But that doesn't necessarily make them a bargain, writes Kelly Evans.

headline: Brazil Market's Fall Outpaces Others
summary: Brazil, a bellwether for emerging markets across the globe, saw its shares plunge nearly 10% before recovering somewhat, diving far more than markets in the U.S. and raising questions about the performance of developing economies amid the rout.

headline: Fed International-Finance Head Sheets to Leave
summary: D. Nathan Sheets, the Fed's head of international finance who has been deeply involved in dealing with the fallout from Europe's debt crisis, is stepping down.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: How to Replace the Jets' Secret Weapon
summary: Joe McKnight and Jeremy Kerley are the leading candidates to take up the slack created by the loss of Brad Smith to Buffalo.

headline: Software Billionaire Bankrolled Arts and GOP
summary: Charles Wyly, a Dallas billionaire entrepreneur who won acclaim for his patronage of the arts, but whose business practices drew scrutiny in recent years, culminating in federal civil-fraud charges, died at 77 after car accident.

headline: Making a Bet on Brooklyn
summary: When Roulette launches its new season on Sept. 15, it will be in a 5,000-square-foot theater in downtown Brooklyn, an area rapidly gaining a reputation for its burgeoning performing-arts venues as much as for its new basketball arena.

headline: Students Make Small Gains on Tests
summary: New York City elementary and middle school students made small gains on statewide English and math tests this year, the state Education Department said on Monday.

headline: Building Permits Jump
summary: New construction permits in New York are on the rise, a sign that the city's ailing construction industry may be picking up steam.

headline: Rethinking the NYC Triathlon
summary: From the river to the payment, here's a look at this year's Nautica New York City Triathlon, which has been overshadowed by the deaths of two competitors.

headline: Triathlon Eyes Changes After Deaths
summary: New York City Triathlon officials said they were considering changes to the swimming portion of the event after a second participant in Sunday's race died.

headline: A Simpler and Safer Time Recalled
summary: Wayne Curtis's innocent use of the term "carom" ("to follow a haphazard course: They carom down a road") In his review of "L.L. Bean" by James L. Witherell (Bookshelf, Aug. 4), caromed me into memories of my innocent youth.

headline: Downgrade Ripples Across Businesses
summary: The ripple effects of S&P's downgrade spread through the financial system with some of the nation's biggest life insurers, securities clearinghouses and investment funds losing their triple-A ratings.

headline: Breathing Easier With Sinus Surgery
summary: When your sinuses are blocked, an increasingly popular option is endoscopic sinus surgery. The effectiveness of the surgery has been mixed in scientific studies, but recent research shows it improves quality of life for many, scientists say.

headline: Majorcan Village House
summary: This six-bedroom "señorial" house in a mountain village has been restored by its current owner, an Emmy-nominated director.

headline: Foodies Get Intimate
summary: Restaurants' appetite for space has shrunk dramatically since the recession, say real estate brokers, as new owners look to avoid the huge rents that brought down their predecessors.

headline: Turkish Stocks Drop the Most in Three Years
summary: Turkish stocks fell 7.1% Monday, the biggest drop in nearly three years, as investors shunned global risk and appeared to reject a defense by the country's central bank governor of his monetary policy.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Aug. 9, 2011

headline: Austerity, Economy, Stillness
summary: Unlike his angst-ridden colleagues the Abstract Expressionists, George Ault aimed not at revealing the invisible, but at commenting on the seen.

headline: From a Home Hotel to the Hospital Tent
summary: Lisa Perry celebrates the launch of her collection of limited-edition dresses and a benefit for the Southampton Hospital's emergency department raises $2 million.

headline: Capital One Nears Deal for HSBC's Card Unit
summary: Capital One is nearing a deal to buy the U.S. credit-card portfolio of HSBC Holdings. A deal, if struck, would be Capital One's second big move in as many months.

headline: Bargain Hunters, Beware
summary: Selloffs are a great time to look for bargains—with one caveat: They make all stocks look cheap, increasing the risk that your bargain is really an overpriced bust.

headline: Crash Involved City Worker
summary: A 10-year-old Australian girl on a family vacation was killed when a car driven by an on-duty New York City public-housing supervisor broadsided the minivan she was in, authorities and family friends said Monday.

headline: To Save a Marriage, Split Up?
summary: Separating is difficult and success is hard to predict, but for some marriages, it's a last, best resort.

headline: Stephens: Is Obama Smart?
summary: A case study in stupid is as stupid does.

headline: South Korea Stampede Forces Halt
summary: In line with many other markets in the region, South Korea's Kospi stock index was down around 3% for much of the day. Then it fell off a cliff.

headline: Max Boot: The Afghan Mission and the SEAL Tragedy
summary: The best way to honor our special forces is not to make them win wars on their own.

headline: Exxon Sets Indonesia Sales
summary: Exxon Mobil is selling some depleting natural-gas assets in Indonesia that are at the center of a human-rights lawsuit against the company, but the energy giant said it will maintain a presence in the country.

headline: Eric Chaney and Jean Sorasio: The Global Economy Is Still Growing
summary: Markets are overreacting to temporary bad news.

headline: Oil Prices Drop More Than 6%
summary: Crude prices settle at their lowest level in almost nine months after Standard & Poor's downgrade of U.S. debt fed fears of weakening demand in the world's largest crude consumer.

headline: Strauss-Kahn Sued By New York Maid
summary: The hotel maid who accused former IMF chief Dominique Strauss-Kahn of sexually assaulting her in a New York hotel filed a civil lawsuit alleging that the "violent and sadistic" attack had done her permanent damage.

headline: A Retooled Giants O-Line, Without the Pranks...So Far
summary: Without veterans like Rich Seubert and Shawn Andrews, the protectors of Eli Manning have a new look.
